text: Have just setup AWS Lightsail and S3. Just wondering what everyone else does regarding their working environment? I've been using Tagadab and basically network mount a remote folder on my local machines and put all my source code into there. This allows me to pick up the source code from multiple machines/devices. Pycharm is OK with this setup as it's effectively a local drive. Sometimes I do quick edits from my phone via SSH and Nano. Are any of you doing something similar with S3? I'm currently investigating how to mount S3 as a network drive. Are there any known issues? Will also be looking at mounting the S3 in the Ubuntu instance on Lightsail to save having to SCP source code. Will be interesting to see how others setup their environments.

text:
Correct me if I'm wrong (I probably am!) but with GitHub, I have to commit my changes every time I edit a file/project and then pull them back every time I change machines? With my "old fashioned" approach all I have to do is ctrl-s in Pycharm and my code is updated on the cloud. I understand that there may be conflicts if I ever had the project open on multiple machines, but the whole point is that I'm only ever using one machine/device at a time as I'm not an octopus. Also, the android app doesn't allow editing of files and the browser only allows it if the web page is loaded in desktop mode.
Forgetting to commit changes when closing a project is a real world issue. My method of mounting a remote folder is equivalent to using Dropbox, Google drive, etc. Perhaps I've totally misunderstood how GitHub works, but it doesn't seem to be a very intuitive way to sync projects across multiple devices. It looks great for publishing projects with multiple users but that doesn't work for me.

Forgetting to commit changes when closing a project is a real world issue. My method of mounting a remote folder is equivalent to using Dropbox, Google drive, etc. Perhaps I've totally misunderstood how GitHub works, but it doesn't seem to be a very intuitive way to sync projects across multiple devices. It looks great for publishing projects with multiple users but that doesn't work for me.

text:
I think you’re conflating three separate issues. 

You 100% should have all of your code under version control, whether that is with GitHub or some other service.

As far as synchronising work in progress across multiple devices, I personally like to use Dropbox.

As far as deployment of production code to your VPC, I like to use ansible but I know that Docker is a popular option.

elements.text: I think you’re conflating three separate issues.
You 100% should have all of your code under version control, whether that is with GitHub or some other service.
As far as synchronising work in progress across multiple devices, I personally like to use Dropbox.
As far as deployment of production code to your VPC, I like to use ansible but I know that Docker is a popular option.

text:
So I have copies of my GitHub repos checked out to a Dropbox folder and any changes I make to my working copies are automatically synced with Dropbox. 

I push my commits to GitHub about once a day to make sure my collaborators have access in case I get hit by a bus etc. Or I’ll push if the changes need to be deployed to production. 

Managing infrastructure with ansible means that the setup of my servers is described in code that can similarly be version controlled. Deploying trading code to production is a case of running ansible tasks that will pull the relevant code from GitHub.

elements.text: So I have copies of my GitHub repos checked out to a Dropbox folder and any changes I make to my working copies are automatically synced with Dropbox.
I push my commits to GitHub about once a day to make sure my collaborators have access in case I get hit by a bus etc. Or I’ll push if the changes need to be deployed to production.

Managing infrastructure with ansible means that the setup of my servers is described in code that can similarly be version controlled. Deploying trading code to production is a case of running ansible tasks that will pull the relevant code from GitHub.

text:
I work as a PLC programmer in my full time job and we use Dropbox for everything, so I'm familiar with using it, which is why I replicated a similar setup with my own VPC.
I totally agree that I need to update my way of thinking and start using a proper version control system as I now have a lot more projects. For my needs, a centralised system seems to be the best fit.
All I need to do now is work out the easiest way to:
a) get Pycharm to automatically sync to subversion or similar when using my main dev machine
b) do simple edits/bug fixes from an Android device with automatic syncing
c) pull the code into my VPS and launch the bot. I normally use a script for this as I compile to pyc, copy to ~/ and launch, so I could potentially use that to pull the latest version before launching
d) be able to carry out minor edits from within the VPS when logged in via SSH
Does that sound feasible, or am I still pissing in the wind?

c) pull the code into my VPS and launch the bot. I normally use a script for this as I compile to pyc, copy to ~/ and launch, so I could potentially use that to pull the latest version before launching

Does that sound feasible, or am I still pissing in the wind?

text: Pycharm end sorted with GitHub.

elements.text: Pycharm end sorted with GitHub.

text:
b, c: You are able to edit code in the mobile view of GitHub. There is a small pen icon top right when you view a file ( iOS, safari and Firefox ). If you want automatic syncing, GitHub has a feature called Actions. On every push of code, it can ssh to your vps and run whatever commands you want.

Is d a good idea when you can just edit the code with syntax highlighting elsewhere? Any edits you make to the files would need to be committed or you risk merge conflicts/code loss next time code is automatically updated on the server

There are tonnes of ways to achieve what you want, just comes down to preference and the initial learning time

elements.text:

Is d a good idea when you can just edit the code with syntax highlighting elsewhere? Any edits you make to the files would need to be committed or you risk merge conflicts/code loss next time code is automatically updated on the server

There are tonnes of ways to achieve what you want, just comes down to preference and the initial learning time
